In a more realistic rabies model, Murray [1993] and Murray et al. [1986] separated the types of rabies cases into nonfurious and furious types, denoted here by I and F, respectively. Animals with furious rabies as opposed to nonfurious rabies are more aggressive and may attack anything that moves; they become confused and wander randomly ( Murray et al. [1986]). In their model, it is assumed that rabies is spread via animals with the furious type. Animals become infected with rabies, stage I, then may progress to the furious type, F. For this model, there also exist traveling wave solutions, provided . With parameter values for rabies in foxes, Murray [1993] calculated a spreading speed of 51 km/year. Reaction‐diffusion models of the type ( 5) have been applied to the spread of hantaviruses and West Nile virus ( Abramson et al. [2003], Lewis et al. [2006], Maidana and Yang [2009]). Reaction‐diffusion models can offer some tractability, allowing to be calculated. However, this tractability does come at a cost. These models assume that dispersal is short range, which cannot always be justified.
